FacilityName: City Of Norfolk West Water Plant

_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Self Contained Breathing Apparatus / Chlorine Scrubber

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Norfolk Water  Division is comprised of two (2) Water Treatment Plants and a staff of 15
employees.  This includes the West Water Treatment Plant located at 300 South 49th Street and the 
East Water Treatment Plant located at 111 South 1st Street.

1. Accidential Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy - Water Staff is trained on safe 
chlorine operating and handling procedures.  Staff also performs monthly preventive maintenance and 
checks on the chlorination, chlorine scrubber, and leak detection systems.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the Norfolk Fire Division, which activates the Local Emergency Operations Plan (LEOP) and notifies any potential neighbors.  Norfolk Fire Division is a member of the Elkhorn Valley LEPC.

2. Regulated Substances - The West Water Treatment Plant uses chlorine as a disinfectant.  We have
two (2) one ton chlorine cylinders on line at all times.  We could have as many as two (2) additional one
ton cylinders on hand at any given time for a total of four (4) one ton cylinders on site.

3.   A) Worst Case Scenario - A possible broken cylinder valve on a one ton chlorine cyclinder will release 
chlorine gas.  Chlorine gas can travel a distance of 1.3 miles.  If this type of leakage would occur, we 
would activate the Emergency Response Team to protect the residents in the affected area.  Next step,
we would notify Chem Trec Response Team.

      B) Alternative  Release Scenario - A leaking lead gasket that seals an attached line onto the regulator
could possibly release a chlorine vapor cloud at a rate of 15 lbs. Per minute.  This cloud could travel a 
distance of 0.10 miles.  The chlorine cylinders are stored inside a concrete building and are monitored 
by a chlorine gas detection system.  When the detection system detects 1.5 ppm of chlorine gas, the
emergency chlorine scrubber system will become active.  If this type of scenario would occur our 
trained staff and emergency scru

bber can migrate the off site consequences.

4. Five Year Accident History - We have not had any accidential releases in the last five years using
one ton chlorine cyclinders.

5. Emergency Response Program - Our Emergency Response Program is to utilize an on-site chlorine
scrubber which is activated when chlorine gas is detected.  The scrubber has the ablitiy to consume
a one ton chlorine cylinder within 25 minutes.  Water Treatment Staff is also trained and ready to respond
to a chlorine leak.  In the event of a leak the Water Treatment Staff would activate the Emergency Plan, which includes procedures for notification of the Norfolk Fire Division.  Norfolk Fire Division would activate the Local Emergency Operations Plan (LEOP) and notifies any affected neighbors.  Norfolk Fire Division is also a member of the Elkhorn Valley LEPC, which assists with contacting Chem Trec, and other agencies that initiates response from a HAZMAT Team.

6.  Planned Changes To Improve Safety - We will keep up with the latest technology for safe chlorine use 
and update procedures as needed.

7.  The population includes a trailor court with approximately 70 residents and a grade school with an 
approximate enrollment of 75, 5 businesses with approximately 40 employees.
